reasoning: Parsing medical procedure input and identifying key components
Identifying organs affected by procedure based on mechanism of action using LLM analysis
Gathering evidence from medical literature for organ-specific effects using LLM
Assessing risk levels based on procedure mechanism and patient factors

kidneys.mechanism: Contrast agents filtered by glomeruli, concentrated in tubules

brain.mechanism: Gadolinium can cross blood-brain barrier and accumulate in tissue

liver.mechanism: Limited liver involvement in contrast elimination

reasoning: Synthesizing evidence-based recommendations using LLM analysis while categorizing by evidence quality
Critically evaluating recommendations against recent evidence and identifying debunked claims

known_recommendations.rationale: Increases urine flow rate and reduces concentration of contrast agent in tubules, minimizing direct nephrotoxic effects
known_recommendations.evidence_level: Strong - Multiple RCTs and guidelines (ESR, ACR)
known_recommendations.timing: 500ml saline 1-2 hours before, continue 6-12 hours after

known_recommendations.intervention: Monitor kidney function in at-risk patients
known_recommendations.rationale: Early detection of contrast-induced nephropathy allows for prompt intervention and prevents progression to acute kidney injury
known_recommendations.evidence_level: Strong - Standard of care per nephrology guidelines
known_recommendations.timing: Baseline creatinine within 7 days, follow-up at 48-72 hours post-procedure

known_recommendations.rationale: NSAIDs reduce renal blood flow via prostaglandin inhibition, compounding contrast-induced vasoconstriction
known_recommendations.evidence_level: Strong - Consistent evidence across multiple studies
known_recommendations.timing: 48-72 hours before and after contrast exposure

potential_recommendations.rationale: Antioxidant properties may reduce oxidative stress and free radical damage from contrast agents. Acts as glutathione precursor.
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Mixed - Some positive RCTs but multiple negative studies and meta-analyses show conflicting results
potential_recommendations.dosing: 600mg orally twice daily for 2 days starting day before procedure
potential_recommendations.limitations: 2018 Cochrane review found no significant benefit; still used in some centers

potential_recommendations.rationale: Magnesium deficiency associated with increased nephrotoxicity; supplementation may maintain cellular energy and reduce calcium influx
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Limited - Small studies suggest benefit but larger RCTs needed
potential_recommendations.dosing: Magnesium sulfate 3g in 250ml saline over 1 hour before procedure
potential_recommendations.limitations: Mechanism unclear, optimal dosing not established

potential_recommendations.rationale: Alkalinization of tubular fluid may reduce formation of reactive oxygen species and Tamm-Horsfall protein precipitation
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Moderate - Several positive studies but some negative trials
potential_recommendations.dosing: 154 mEq/L in D5W at 3ml/kg/hr for 1hr before, then 1ml/kg/hr for 6hrs after
potential_recommendations.limitations: Not superior to saline in all studies; logistically complex

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: No scientific evidence for enhanced elimination of contrast agents; may cause electrolyte imbalances and dehydration
debunked_claims.debunked_by: American Society of Nephrology, National Kidney Foundation
debunked_claims.evidence: Systematic reviews show no benefit and potential harm from commercial detox products
debunked_claims.why_harmful: Can lead to dehydration, electrolyte disturbances, and delayed medical care

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: No peer-reviewed evidence for gadolinium elimination; some herbs (aristolochia) are nephrotoxic
debunked_claims.evidence: Case reports of acute kidney injury from herbal products
debunked_claims.why_harmful: Potential drug interactions and direct nephrotoxicity

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Contrast agents eliminated by glomerular filtration, not affected by dietary interventions
debunked_claims.evidence: Gadolinium elimination follows first-order kinetics independent of diet
debunked_claims.why_harmful: May cause hypoglycemia, nutrient deficiencies, and false sense of protection

known_recommendations.intervention: No specific interventions required for healthy patients
known_recommendations.rationale: Gadolinium retention in brain has no proven clinical consequences in patients with normal kidney function
known_recommendations.evidence_level: Strong - Multiple safety studies and FDA review

potential_recommendations.rationale: Linear gadolinium agents show greater brain retention than macrocyclic agents; cumulative effects unknown
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Precautionary - Based on imaging studies showing retention
potential_recommendations.dosing: Use lowest effective dose, prefer macrocyclic agents
potential_recommendations.limitations: No proven clinical harm, may delay necessary imaging

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Blood-brain barrier prevents most oral supplements from accessing brain tissue; no evidence for gadolinium removal
debunked_claims.debunked_by: Neuropharmacology research, lack of clinical trials
debunked_claims.evidence: No peer-reviewed studies showing brain gadolinium reduction from supplements
debunked_claims.why_harmful: Expensive, false hope, may contain unlisted ingredients

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: No evidence that chelating agents remove gadolinium from brain tissue; may be harmful
debunked_claims.debunked_by: FDA warnings, multiple medical societies including American College of Radiology
debunked_claims.evidence: EDTA and other chelators can cause kidney damage, electrolyte imbalances, and cardiac arrhythmias
debunked_claims.why_harmful: Serious adverse effects including death; no proven benefit for gadolinium removal

known_recommendations.intervention: Monitor liver function in patients with hepatic disease
known_recommendations.rationale: Severely impaired hepatic function may affect gadolinium elimination kinetics
known_recommendations.timing: Baseline and 48-72 hour follow-up in severe hepatic impairment

potential_recommendations.rationale: Theoretical benefit from reducing oxidative stress, though liver is not primary elimination route
potential_recommendations.limitations: No specific studies with gadolinium contrast; unclear clinical relevance

potential_recommendations.rationale: Silymarin may have hepatoprotective effects through antioxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanisms
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Limited - Some studies in other hepatotoxic contexts
potential_recommendations.limitations: No studies specific to contrast agents; variable product quality

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Liver has natural detoxification processes; no evidence that commercial cleanses enhance gadolinium elimination
debunked_claims.evidence: No scientific basis for enhanced liver 'cleansing' beyond normal physiology
debunked_claims.why_harmful: May cause diarrhea, electrolyte imbalances, and interfere with medications

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: No mechanism for gadolinium elimination via colon; potentially dangerous procedure
debunked_claims.debunked_by: Multiple case reports of complications, FDA warnings
debunked_claims.evidence: Risk of electrolyte imbalances, infections, and rectal perforation
debunked_claims.why_harmful: Serious complications including death reported; no medical justification

known_recommendations.rationale: Limited data available for this organ system with the specified procedure
known_recommendations.timing: Before and after procedure as clinically indicated
